raw_text: This& quot; core parser& quot; has been the subject of a number of computational implementations, including Marcus ' s deterministic parser (1980), Description theory (henceforth, D-theory) (Marcus et al (1983)), and Abney ' s licensing based model (1987, 1989)

This model is interesting in that it does not allow the parser to employ delay tactics, such as using a lookahead buffer (Marcus (1980), Marcus et al (1983)), or waiting for the head of a phrase to appear in the input before constructing that phrase (Abney (1987, 1989), Pritehett (1992))
clean_text: This model is interesting in that it does not allow the parser to employ delay tactics, such as using a lookahead buffer (Marcus (1980), Marcus et al (1983)), or waiting for the head of a phrase to appear in the input before constructing that phrase (Abney (1987, 1989), Pritehett (1992)).

raw_text: The original D-theory model (Marcus et al (1983)) is also more powerful, because it allows the right-most daughter of a node to be lowered under a sibling node
clean_text: The original D-theory model (Marcus et al (1983)) is also more powerful, because it allows the right-most daughter of a node to be lowered under a sibling node.

raw_text: More on Dominance Links Dominance links are quite common in tree description formalisms, where they were already in use in D-theory (Marcus et al, 1983) and in quasi-tree semantics for fb TAGs (Vijay-Shanker, 1992)
clean_text: More on Dominance Links Dominance links are quite common in tree description formalisms, where they were already in use in D-theory (Marcus et al, 1983) and in quasi-tree semantics for fb TAGs (Vijay-Shanker, 1992).
